location: The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.

lines.text: Enter ACHILLES and PATROCLUS

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: I'll heat his blood with Greekish wine to-night, Which with my scimitar I'll cool to-morrow. Patroclus, let us feast him to the height.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Here comes Thersites.
Enter THERSITES

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: How now, thou core of envy! Thou crusty batch of nature, what's the news?

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Why, thou picture of what thou seemest, and idol of idiot worshippers, here's a letter for thee.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: From whence, fragment?

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Why, thou full dish of fool, from Troy.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Who keeps the tent now?

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: The surgeon's box, or the patient's wound.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Well said, adversity! and what need these tricks?

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Prithee, be silent, boy; I profit not by thy talk: thou art thought to be Achilles' male varlet.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Male varlet, you rogue! what's that?

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Why, his masculine whore. Now, the rotten diseases of the south, the guts-griping, ruptures, catarrhs, loads o' gravel i' the back, lethargies, cold palsies, raw eyes, dirt-rotten livers, wheezing lungs, bladders full of imposthume, sciaticas, limekilns i' the palm, incurable bone-ache, and the rivelled fee-simple of the tetter, take and take again such preposterous discoveries!

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Why thou damnable box of envy, thou, what meanest thou to curse thus?

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Do I curse thee?

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Why no, you ruinous butt, you whoreson indistinguishable cur, no.

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: No! why art thou then exasperate, thou idle immaterial skein of sleave-silk, thou green sarcenet flap for a sore eye, thou tassel of a prodigal's purse, thou? Ah, how the poor world is pestered with such waterflies, diminutives of nature!

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Out, gall!

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Finch-egg!

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: My sweet Patroclus, I am thwarted quite From my great purpose in to-morrow's battle. Here is a letter from Queen Hecuba, A token from her daughter, my fair love, Both taxing me and gaging me to keep An oath that I have sworn. I will not break it: Fall Greeks; fail fame; honour or go or stay; My major vow lies here, this I'll obey. Come, come, Thersites, help to trim my tent: This night in banqueting must all be spent. Away, Patroclus!
Exeunt ACHILLES and PATROCLUS

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: With too much blood and too little brain, these two may run mad; but, if with too much brain and too little blood they do, I'll be a curer of madmen. Here's Agamemnon, an honest fellow enough and one that loves quails; but he has not so much brain as earwax: and the goodly transformation of Jupiter there, his brother, the bull,--the primitive statue, and oblique memorial of cuckolds; a thrifty shoeing-horn in a chain, hanging at his brother's leg,--to what form but that he is, should wit larded with malice and malice forced with wit turn him to? To an ass, were nothing; he is both ass and ox: to an ox, were nothing; he is both ox and ass. To be a dog, a mule, a cat, a fitchew, a toad, a lizard, an owl, a puttock, or a herring without a roe, I would not care; but to be Menelaus, I would conspire against destiny. Ask me not, what I would be, if I were not Thersites; for I care not to be the louse of a lazar, so I were not Menelaus! Hey-day! spirits and fires!
Enter HECTOR, TROILUS, AJAX, AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, MENELAUS, and DIOMEDES, with lights

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: We go wrong, we go wrong.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: No, yonder 'tis; There, where we see the lights.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: I trouble you.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: No, not a whit.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Here comes himself to guide you.
Re-enter ACHILLES

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Welcome, brave Hector; welcome, princes all.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: So now, fair prince of Troy, I bid good night. Ajax commands the guard to tend on you.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Thanks and good night to the Greeks' general.

lines.speaker: menelaus
lines.text: Good night, my lord.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Good night, sweet lord Menelaus.

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Sweet draught: 'sweet' quoth 'a! sweet sink, sweet sewer.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Good night and welcome, both at once, to those That go or tarry.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Good night.
Exeunt AGAMEMNON and MENELAUS

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Old Nestor tarries; and you too, Diomed, Keep Hector company an hour or two.

lines.speaker: diomedes
lines.text: I cannot, lord; I have important business, The tide whereof is now. Good night, great Hector.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Give me your hand.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: [Aside to TROILUS]  Follow his torch; he goes to Calchas' tent: I'll keep you company.

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: Sweet sir, you honour me.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: And so, good night. Exit DIOMEDES; ULYSSES and TROILUS following

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Come, come, enter my tent.
Exeunt ACHILLES, HECTOR, AJAX, and NESTOR

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: That same Diomed's a false-hearted rogue, a most unjust knave; I will no more trust him when he leers than I will a serpent when he hisses: he will spend his mouth, and promise, like Brabbler the hound: but when he performs, astronomers foretell it; it is prodigious, there will come some change; the sun borrows of the moon, when Diomed keeps his word. I will rather leave to see Hector, than not to dog him: they say he keeps a Trojan drab, and uses the traitor Calchas' tent: I'll after. Nothing but lechery! all incontinent varlets!
Exit
